position.marginalia_text: Actiones Consulum, aut Decemuirûm, aut Tribunoru[m] militum consulari potestata, aut alioru[m] magistratuu[m], pra[e]terq[uam] Dictatorum, minus meruerunt ponderis, aut examinis politici, quàm actiones Regum. Veruntamen hîc etiam Romana Prudentia, et fortitudo; ciuilis temperantia, et iustitia. Vtinam tam priuatim integra, quàm publicè magnifica.

marginalia.translation: The actions of the Consuls, Decemviri, Military Tribunes with consular authority or other magistrates, except Dictators, deserve less consideration, or political scrutiny than the deeds of Kings. Still in this area there is also Roman Sagacity and Strength, civic restraint and justice. If only these [actions] were as irreproachable privately as they were excellent publicly.

position.marginalia_text: De primis apud Rom. consulibus, quoru[m] alter alterum patria pepulit; moxq[ue] Roma[e] post atrocissima parricidia, à vulnerato hoste vulneratus interiit. Augustinus l. 3. c. 16. de Civitate Dei. Vt etiam idem c. 17. post initia consularis imperii, quibus malis vexata fuerit Rom. Respublica; Dijs non opitulantibus, quos colebat. Duo literata, valdeq[ue] notabilia capita acutissimi Doctoris. Nec spernendi Vivis eruditi Commentarii. Cuius illud memorabile: Homines de plebe, suis actionib[us] praetendebant, se iura populi, et commune[m] Libertatem defendere: patritij contra niti, et multum de commodis vulgi detrahere, ut id sibi apponerent; illo pra[e]textu, quòd dignitatem Senatus tuerentur , quam esse amplissimam è Repub. foret. Sed re vera pro sua potentia quisq[ue] certare. Quod toties infra occurrens, semel hîc videbatur observandum.

marginalia.translation: Of the first Roman consuls, one of whom expelled the other, and soon afterwards perished by a wound inflicted by a wounded enemy, after the most atrocious parricide: Augustine, bk. 3, c. 16 of the City of God. As also in the same book, c. 17: Of the ills by which the Roman commonwealth was vexed after the inauguration of the consulate, while no help was offered by the gods whom the Romans worshipped. Two erudite and highly significant chapters of the extremely perceptive Doctor. One should not disregard Vives' learned Commentary. From which comes this remarkable passage: Men from the common people pretended with their actions to defend the rights of the people and joint liberty; the patricians conversely exerted themselves to take away much from the people’s benefits in order to claim it for themselves, under the pretext that they were guarding the dignity of the Senate, which had to be greatest in the Repubic. But in reality everyone was fighting for his own power. As this happens so often below, it seemed it should be noted here once.

position.marginalia_text: Rex sacrificulus, titularis rex. Species sine re, ad pascendum oculos regiorum fautorum. Elenchus signoru[m]: saepe valde politicus.

marginalia.translation: The 'rex sacrificulus' [the king of sacrifices] was a king in name only. The appearance without the substance, for royal supporters to feast their eyes on. The investigation of signs was often very political.
A snake hides in the grass.

position.marginalia_text: Practica Regia, pro recuperando Regno; primo Privata, et sophistica; deinde publica, et bellica. Astuta, et valida, ni fuisset Brutus vir: et absolutus Artifex utendae occasionis. Nunc animis opus, Aenea: nunc pectore firmo. Quicquid erant hi, aut illi Romani, seu publicae, seu privatae personae, qui erant plaerunq[ue], in sua quisq[ue] functione, enixe prudentes, atq[ue] strenui: certe Livius, semper est Lectu, animadversu[que] dignissimus. Ut ecce a pagina in paginam, ubi ubi [sic] voles. Quod ego de perpaucis dixerim simul eloquentissimis, simul sapientissimis auctoribus.

marginalia.translation: Royal actions to regain the rule: first private and cunning, then public and military. Shrewd and effective [actions], if Brutus had not been a man, and a perfect master in seizing the opportunity. “Now Aeneas, courage is needed, now a resolute mind.” Whoever these or other Romans were, public or private characters, who were generally strenuously prudent and vigorous in their respective capacities, Livy is surely always superbly worth reading and attending to. As you can see page after page, wherever you want. And I would say this only about very few authors, who are both extremely eloquent and extremely wise.
